docs.title: Linux

docs.text: SSL on Centos 7 Frontend Install apache http web server yum install -y httpd mod_ssl Optional: To change the port of apache cd /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf Append the following Listen 80 <IfModule ssl_module> Listen 443 </IfModule> Start server systemctl start httpd systemctl enable httpd Find the document root on your server grep -ri DocumentRoot /etc/httpd You will find an address like /etc/httpd/conf.d/ssl.conf:#DocumentRoot "/var/www/html" Paste your index.html file here echo demo > /var/www/html/index.html If this demos is not available at server:80 Add this to rebootinstructions.sh as well sudo /sbin/iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-port 80 Also change this in the rebootinstructions.sh Change default document root Edit httpd.conf file vi /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf And change DocumentRoot “desired path” Also change <Directory "/home/webmaster/website/www"> i.e. change 2 occurrences of /var/www/html with your desired path Give permission to webmaster chmod 777 /home/webmaster Restart httpd Systemctl restart httpd Stop existing pm2 task for hosting since it is not required now pm2 kill Add exception to the firewall (if you are using firewalld) firewall-cmd –permanent –zone=public –add-service=http firewall-cmd –permanent –zone=public –add-service=https firewall-cmd –reload or Use ufw allow to open your ports 80 & 443 Install epel repository yum install -y epel-release Install cert bot application yum install certbot -y You can search for your server using (if you are not using apache) yum search certbot Install certbot for apache yum install -y python2-certbot-apache Generate ssl use –apache if you know your server else follow certbot certbot --apache -d your-domain if that doesn’t work first run certbot certonly -d your-domain --webroot -w /home/webmaster/website/www Choose option (3: Place files in webroot directory (webroot)) and then certbot --apache -d your-domain Backend For a https front end, all the backend calls should be https as well hence you need to serve back end with https as well Go to /etc/letsencrypt/live/yoursitefolder** Generate keystore using openssl pkcs12 -export -in fullchain.pem -inkey privkey.pem -out keystore.p12 -name tomcat -CAfile chain.pem -caname root Download this and Paste the generated keystore in “src/main/resources/keystore” Or to the jar, since we have used this location in softrade code In application.properties paste the following # The format used for the keystore. It could be set to JKS in case it is a JKS file server.ssl.keyStoreType=PKCS12 # The path to the keystore containing the certificate server.ssl.key-store=classpath:keystore/keystore.p12 # The password used to generate the certificate server.ssl.key-store-password=<your-password-here> # The alias mapped to the certificate server.ssl.keyAlias=tomcat change server.ssl.key-store-password=<your-password-here> to your desired password Also, you can use direct location such as server.ssl.key-store=/root/jar/keystore.p12 Disabling ssl on run time @Configuration public class CustomContainer implements EmbeddedServletContainerCustomizer { @Autowired private SystemPrefService systemPrefService; @Override public void customize(ConfigurableEmbeddedServletContainer container) { if(!systemPrefService.isSSL()) { Ssl ssl = new Ssl(); ssl.setEnabled(false); ssl.setKeyStore(""); container.setSsl(ssl); } } } Step 4-5 have been done in code, simply change the syspref isSSL = true then restart the server Renew License Run certbot --apache -d your-domain Run following command in /etc/letsencrypt/live/your-domain-folder openssl pkcs12 -export -in fullchain.pem -inkey privkey.pem -out keystore.p12 -name tomcat -CAfile chain.pem -caname root Restart spring server Delete SSL sudo certbot delete --cert-name <certname> yum remove -y httpd mod_ssl re-install from top of page

docs.text: Markdown Why Markdown We choose to use markdown (.md) over any other method of writing technical documentation since: * .md files are universal * Developers inherently understand to write docs-as-code approach * Versioning control is possible with GIT * It is opensource and completely free to use * is universally accepted in IDEs and repos like github or bitbucket. * and many more reasons Framework We choose to use MkDocs as our choice of framework to write markdown, since: * Almost no learning curve over markdown * All the navigation and config is in a single mkdocs.yml file * Can instantly serve static website * Could build up a static website which could be hosted in no time. * Very good community support. Important Links Cheat Sheet Markdown in Jetbrains

docs.text: MkDocs For full documentation visit mkdocs.org . Getting Started Python Instal python 3 if not already MacOS brew install python3 pip3 install --upgrade pip Installation pip3 install mkdocs The following are optional if you want to use the material theme for the static website pip3 install mkdocs-material pip3 install mkdocs-material-extensions More on Material for Mkdocs . Project Create python3 -m mkdocs new folder-name Serve python3 -m mkdocs serve Build python3 -m mkdocs build Theme To add a theme to the project add this to the mkdocs.yml file. theme: "material" Logo To change logo of the project add this to the mkdocs.yml file. theme: name: 'material' logo: 'resources/images/logo/umun/800x269.png' favicon: 'resources/images/logo/umun/800x269.png' here resources is a folder in this hierarchy -docs -resources -images -logo ... -mkdocs.yml
